entries.content: Not every objection is an objection; some are statements of fact.
entries.notes: Highlights the importance of distinguishing genuine facts from dismissive statements.

entries.content: Objections are not always dismissive; they can be genuine expressions of satisfaction.
entries.notes: Encourages viewing objections as potential truths rather than outright rejections.

entries.content: Respond to objections with questions to separate facts from smoke screens.
entries.notes: Suggests using questions to probe the validity of objections.

entries.content: Challenge objections by pushing them to the extreme with questions.
entries.notes: Example: 'Did you mean never ever under any circumstances?'

entries.content: When a prospect says 'We're fine thanks,' respond with 'Didn’t you mean to say everything’s perfect?'
entries.notes: Demonstrates how to reframe an objection to keep the conversation going.

entries.content: For 'I have no interest,' ask 'Did you mean never ever under any circumstances would you consider exploring what we do?'
entries.notes: Shows how to escalate the objection to uncover real intent.

entries.content: For 'We already have a supplier,' ask if there’s nothing anyone could do to make them consider an alternative.
entries.notes: Illustrates probing for flexibility behind the objection.

entries.content: For 'I don’t take cold calls,' simply ask 'What do you mean?' to clarify their stance.
entries.notes: Encourages unpacking vague objections to understand the real barrier.

entries.content: Salespeople take prospecting too seriously; it’s about finding the few who need what you offer.
entries.notes: Advises maintaining perspective on rejection frequency.

focus_area: Objection Mindset: Objections = info requests, not rejections
